text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section traditional pulled pork involves
a seven pound bone-in pork but it takes
all day and feeds 14 people but
sometimes you want to be able to make a
smaller batch so instead of starting
with an entire pork butt which by the
way it's just another name for the pork
shoulder I went to the store and I got a
three pound pork shoulder roast it's the
same meat
without the bone a little bit smaller
usually when you buy a shoulder roast
it's been tied up this makes it easier
to roast but since we're not gonna roast
it we're gonna slow cook it I'm gonna
cut apart strings now I'm gonna make a
spice mixture to rub all over the pork
I've got some toasted ground spices
brown sugar dry mustard powder really
good chili powder and salt for the exact
recipe go to nytimes.com slash dining at
this point you could cook the pork right
away but if you have time it really does
get better if you let it sit out for an
hour or two or make this the day before
stick in the fridge and marinate it
overnight when you're ready to cook the
pork you want to do it in a 300 degree
oven for three to four hours it has to
be really tender at the end so that you
can just pull it apart that's why it's
called pulled pork while that's in the
oven you should make the barbecue sauce
this barbecue sauce is tangy it is sweet
but it is very spicy which is how I like
it
I've got ketchup Worcestershire sauce
apple cider vinegar brown sugar dry
mustard powder paprika you can use sweet
or hot I'm using hot cayenne and
molasses now I'm gonna add some hot
sauce to taste you just want to simmer
this together for about 15 minutes it's
gonna start to thicken and then it's
gonna change color and turn a little bit
darker Brown as the sugars caramelize so
this is what the pork looks like when it
comes out of the oven it roasted for
about four hours and then I let it cool
for about an hour if you want to be
delicate about it you could use two
forks and use the forks to kind of rip
the meat apart but really where's the
fun in that
now I'm gonna add the barbecue sauce I'm
gonna add it a little bit at a time
because I don't know that I'm going to
use all of it it depends on how moist
the pork is and how much sauce there is
this amount of pork will feed eight you
could serve it traditionally in a
hamburger bun or a soft roll maybe with
some coleslaw on top if you like or you
know you could just eat it with a fork
you
